sections.Interpretation: Dhana Yoga forms when the lords of wealth houses (2nd - accumulated wealth, 11th - gains/income) combine. This creates a direct channel between earning capacity and wealth accumulation, indicating financial prosperity.
sections.Principle: The 2nd house is the vault—what we store and accumulate. The 11th house is the income stream—what comes to us. When their lords connect, income flows into savings, creating lasting wealth.
sections.Formation: 2nd lord and 11th lord in: (1) Conjunction, (2) Mutual aspect, (3) Exchange, (4) Either in the other's house. Strongest when occurring in 2nd, 11th, or a kendra.
sections.Enhancements: Strengthened when Jupiter aspects the combination, when either lord is in own or exalted sign, when occurring in signs of wealth-giving planets (Taurus, Libra, Jupiter's signs).
sections.Results: Steady wealth accumulation, good income that translates to savings, financial security. The specific nature of wealth depends on the planets and signs involved.

sections.Interpretation: Lakshmi Yoga forms when the 9th lord is powerful and Venus occupies its own or exaltation sign in a kendra or trikona. Named after the goddess of wealth, this yoga brings prosperity through fortunate circumstances and blessings rather than just hard work.
sections.Principle: Lakshmi is the goddess who chooses whom to bless. When the 9th house (fortune, divine grace) is strong and Venus (significator of Lakshmi) is well-placed, the goddess's blessings flow into the life.
sections.Formation: 9th lord in own/exaltation/friend's sign AND Venus in Taurus, Libra, or Pisces in houses 1, 4, 5, 7, 9, or 10.
sections.Results: Wealth that seems to come easily, luxury, beautiful possessions, fortunate marriage. The native is blessed with comforts and rarely experiences true poverty. Grace in financial matters.
sections.Variations: Some texts require both conditions, others allow either. The stronger both factors, the more pronounced the results.

sections.Interpretation: Neecha Bhanga Raja Yoga forms when a debilitated planet has its debilitation 'cancelled' (bhanga) through specific conditions, transforming apparent weakness into exceptional strength. This is one of astrology's most profound teachings—that our greatest weaknesses, properly addressed, become our greatest strengths.
sections.Cancellation Conditions: (1) Lord of debilitation sign in kendra from Lagna or Moon, (2) Lord of exaltation sign in kendra from Lagna or Moon, (3) Debilitated planet conjunct or aspected by its debilitation sign lord, (4) Debilitated planet in exalted navamsa, (5) Debilitated planet conjunct an exalted planet.
sections.Principle: A debilitated planet represents a karmic weakness—an area where we must struggle. When cancellation occurs, the struggle itself becomes the path to mastery. The native rises through overcoming the very weakness indicated.
sections.Results: Rise to prominence, often from humble or difficult beginnings. Success that comes after initial struggle. The native develops exceptional abilities precisely in the area of initial weakness. Often indicates a dramatic turnaround in life.
sections.Examples: Sun debilitated in Libra but Libra lord Venus in kendra—initial lack of confidence transforms into diplomatic leadership. Mars debilitated in Cancer but Moon in kendra—initial fear transforms into protective courage.

sections.Interpretation: Kahala Yoga forms when the lords of 4th and 9th houses are in mutual kendras and the Lagna lord is strong. This creates a bold, energetic leader with both emotional stability (4th) and dharmic conviction (9th). The native charges forward like a war elephant (kahala).
sections.Formation: 4th lord and 9th lord in kendra from each other (1, 4, 7, or 10 houses apart) AND Lagna lord is strong (in own sign, exalted, or well-placed).
sections.Results: Bold and courageous, leads others, stubborn in convictions, energetic throughout life. The native has both the emotional foundation (4th) and philosophical conviction (9th) to lead without wavering. May be seen as headstrong.
sections.Variations: Some texts define this as 4th lord in own/exaltation AND 9th lord in kendra, or 4th and 9th lords conjoined with strong Lagna lord.

sections.Interpretation: Saraswati Yoga forms when Jupiter, Venus, and Mercury occupy kendra, trikona, or 2nd houses from Lagna, AND Jupiter is in its own, exaltation, or friendly sign. Named after the goddess of learning and arts, this yoga bestows exceptional intellectual and artistic abilities.
sections.Formation: Jupiter, Venus, and Mercury all in houses 1, 2, 4, 5, 7, 9, or 10 AND Jupiter in Sagittarius, Pisces, Cancer, or friendly signs.
sections.Results: Exceptional learning ability, skilled in arts and sciences, eloquent speech, poetic talent. The native becomes learned in multiple fields, may be a writer, teacher, or artist. Respected for wisdom and knowledge.
sections.Goddess: Saraswati is the goddess of knowledge, music, arts, and learning. Her blessings flow through the intellectual planets when properly aligned.

sections.Interpretation: Amala Yoga (also called Mala Yoga) forms when a natural benefic (Jupiter, Venus, Mercury, or waxing Moon) occupies the 10th house from Lagna or Moon. 'Amala' means pure or spotless—this yoga gives a pure, lasting reputation.
sections.Formation: Jupiter, Venus, Mercury, or waxing Moon in the 10th house from Lagna or from Moon.
sections.Results: Spotless reputation, fame for good deeds, lasting legacy. The native is known for virtuous actions and maintains good standing throughout life. Professional success with ethical foundation. Even after death, the reputation remains honorable.
sections.Variations: Stronger when the benefic is in its own or exalted sign. Multiple benefics in the 10th increase the yoga's power. Check both from Lagna and Moon.

sections.Interpretation: Kala Sarpa Yoga forms when all seven planets (Sun through Saturn) are hemmed between Rahu and Ketu. This creates a karmic constraint where life seems bound by fate, with sudden reversals and intense experiences. Controversial among astrologers—some consider it highly significant, others dismiss it entirely.
sections.Formation: All planets (Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Saturn) on one side of the Rahu-Ketu axis. No planet should be conjunct Rahu or Ketu (partial yoga if conjunction exists).
sections.Traditional View: Indicates serpent-related karma, obstacles, sudden rises and falls, constraint followed by eventual liberation. The native may feel fated or trapped until spiritual practices break the pattern.
sections.Modern View: Many highly successful people have this yoga. It may indicate intense focus in one direction of life, karmic acceleration, or spiritual catalyst rather than pure affliction.
sections.Types: 12 types based on which house Rahu occupies. Ananta (Rahu in 1st) through Shankha (Rahu in 12th). Each has different implications.
sections.Cancellation: Some texts say a planet conjunct Rahu or Ketu partially cancels the yoga. Others require specific remedial measures.

sections.Interpretation: When two or more Pancha Mahapurusha Yogas occur in the same chart, an exceptional individual is indicated. The qualities of each yoga combine, creating a multifaceted great person with the strengths of multiple planetary archetypes.
sections.Principle: Each Mahapurusha Yoga (Ruchaka, Bhadra, Hamsa, Malavya, Shasha) represents mastery in one domain. Multiple yogas indicate mastery across domains—a true 'great person' (mahapurusha).
sections.Combinations: Ruchaka + Hamsa: Warrior-philosopher, Jupiter + Mars. Bhadra + Malavya: Artist-intellectual, Mercury + Venus. Hamsa + Shasha: Wise administrator, Jupiter + Saturn. Each combination has its own character.
sections.Rarity: Single Mahapurusha Yogas are uncommon in pure form; multiple are rare. However, even partial formations contribute their qualities.

metadata.condition: Two or more Pancha Mahapurusha Yogas in same chart
